trigger: User navigates to memory section or performs memory management actions

dataFlow.response: Database → memory-service → API → React Query → MemorySection UI updates

errorPaths.network: Show error message, retry button available

behaviorDifferences.memory: Manual memory creation with full form validation and category selection
behaviorDifferences.chat: Automatic memory creation from chat context with AI-determined categories

sharedEndpoints.processingDifferences: Memory UI uses POST /api/memories/manual with user input, chat uses POST /api/memories with AI-extracted content

impactAnalysis.memoryCreation: Both manual and automatic memory creation invalidate same cache keys
impactAnalysis.userExperience: Manual entries show immediate feedback, chat-triggered memories appear in background
impactAnalysis.categoryMapping: Manual selection vs AI-determined category assignment may create inconsistencies

dataFlow.response: Database counts → API → React Query → Overview UI update

userFlow: User navigates to memory section
System loads lightweight overview with counts by category
User sees total memories and category breakdown without loading full content
Category tabs show counts (All, Preferences, Personal Context, Instructions, Food & Diet, Goals)
Overview updates automatically after memory operations

dataFlow.response: Memory creation → API response → Query invalidation → UI refresh

userFlow: User clicks 'Add Memory' button
Modal opens with memory entry form
User enters content, selects category (preferences/personal_context/instructions/food_diet/goals) and importance (low/medium/high)
System validates form inputs
Memory created with embeddings and metadata
Query cache invalidated
UI updates with new memory in appropriate category
Success toast notification shown

memory-browsing.trigger: User clicks 'Show My Stored Memories' button

dataFlow.response: Database → API → React Query → Memory cards display

userFlow: User clicks 'Show My Stored Memories' button (manual loading for performance)
System loads all memories from database
Memories displayed in cards with category badges and importance levels
Each memory shows content, keywords, creation date, and access count
Category filtering applied client-side
Individual memory management options available

category-navigation.trigger: User clicks category tab (All, Preferences, Personal, Context, Instructions)

dataFlow.response: Filtered memories → UI update with category-specific content

userFlow: User sees category tabs with counts (All, Preferences, Personal Context, Instructions, Food & Diet, Goals)
User clicks on category tab
System filters memories client-side by category
Label filtering options appear for selected category
User can select/deselect labels to further filter memories
Explanatory card shows category description and purpose
Only memories matching selected category and labels displayed
Category-specific operations available

label-filtering.trigger: User selects category with available labels

dataFlow.request: CategorySelection → Client-side label extraction → Label filter UI
dataFlow.response: Label selection → Client-side filtering → Filtered memory display

userFlow: User selects a category (not 'All')
System extracts unique labels from memories in that category
Label filtering UI appears with available labels and counts
User can select/deselect individual labels or select all
Memories are filtered client-side by selected labels
Label selection state is maintained per category
Label counts update based on visible memories

displayHierarchy.tertiary: Keywords (outline badges, limited to 3 + more indicator)

labelSystem.migrationStatus: completed - enhanced semantic labeling system implemented

bulk-operations.trigger: User selects multiple memories via checkboxes

dataFlow.response: Bulk deletion → API response → Query invalidation → UI refresh

userFlow: User can select multiple memories with checkboxes
Select all/clear selection options available
Selected count displayed in real-time
Bulk delete button enabled when memories selected
Confirmation dialog shown before bulk deletion
Bulk operation executed with progress feedback
Query cache invalidated
UI updates with removed memories and updated counts

memory-deletion.trigger: User clicks delete button on individual memory

dataFlow.response: Memory deactivation → API response → Query invalidation → UI refresh

userFlow: User clicks delete button on individual memory
Confirmation dialog shown
User confirms deletion
Memory marked as inactive (soft delete)
Query cache invalidated
UI updates memory counts and removes from list
Success notification shown

GET /api/memories/overview.description: Returns lightweight memory statistics and category counts
GET /api/memories/overview.response: { total: number, categories: { preferences: number, personal_context: number, instructions: number, food_diet: number, goals: number } }

GET /api/memories.description: Fetches all user memories with category filtering
GET /api/memories.response: [{ id: string, content: string, category: string, importance: number, keywords: string[], createdAt: string, accessCount: number }]

POST /api/memories/manual.description: Creates a new memory entry from manual user input
POST /api/memories/manual.requestBody: { content: string, category: string, importance: number }
POST /api/memories/manual.response: { id: string, content: string, category: string, confidence: number }

DELETE /api/memories/:id.description: Soft delete individual memory (marks as inactive)

labels.description: Labels for subcategorization within each category

keywords.description: Auto-extracted keywords for search and filtering

migrationNotes.categoryMigration: Old categories like 'background' migrated to 'personal_context' category with 'background' as label
migrationNotes.labelSystemImplemented: Labels column added for enhanced filtering and categorization
migrationNotes.dataIntegrity: All existing memories preserved with proper category/label mapping
migrationNotes.uiDisplayOrder: Category Badge → Labels (small badges) → Keywords (outline badges)
